loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is engaged in running a grocery store selling household items (canned goods, rice, etc.) She has been in business for 15 years and earns a monthly net income of 4000 Php. Teresita is from the village of Balasdiot, part of the Municipality of Baliangao. She is 58 years old, married, and blessed with 3 adult children.

In 2009, Teresita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting her 1st loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock for the store to sell.
  
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase new stock

loans.name: Roy

texts.en:
Roy V. is from the village of Upper Salug Dako, Mahayag ZDS. He is 28 years old. Roy is an individual member of PMPC. Roy  is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Roy owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, one main source of income for the business comes from their piggery. Roy has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

 In 2009, Roy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roy is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Roy from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family.

loans.use: additional capital for piggery

loans.name: Soung

texts.en:
Soung P., 48, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She and her husband make and sell baskets at the local market and are able to make about US$ 5 in profit every day. This couple has four children; two are in school and other two work in construction and in a garment factory. 

Soung P. would like to take out a loan of US$ 600 to purchase more materials like bamboo to make more baskets to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase bamboo and materials to make baskets

loans.name: Agapita

texts.en:
Agapita L.  is from the village of Lower Mahayag, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 55 years old.

Agapita is married and has 3 children. To make a living, Agapita owns & operates in Agricultural sector running in ricefield.The main source of income for the business comes from their rice field. Agapita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

 In 2009, Agapita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Agapita is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and fertilizer for their farm. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Agapita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer for rice field

loans.name: Roeun

texts.en:
Roeun R., 29, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She raises pigs and makes cow rope to sell at the market, typically making US$ 4 each day. Her husband has been walking with his bicycle, selling snow cones since 2007, and is able to make about US$ 4 in profit each day as well. This family has two young children living at home to support. 

Roeun R. would like to take out a loan of US$ 300 to purchase a motorbike for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband's snow cone sales

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose S., aged 38, is a tailor at Mathare north specializing in making covers for chairs, beds and tables. She is married to Joseph Irungu who is a salesman and together they have one daughter — Sharon, aged 16 and in high school. Mathare north is a slum area and Rose’s customers are mostly ladies of low income. She has been running this business for six years and her monthly income is Kshs 11,400 which adds to her husband's income.

Rose was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of Thika Road office. With the Kshs 80000 loan, She plans to purchase covers, fabrics, and threads. She will also use Kshs 15000 from the loan to open another shop in the same area. If this loan boosts her business she will open a much bigger workshop to train, and later employ, other women so that they can also support their families.

In the future, Rose plans to start a tailoring college to empower young ladies from Mathare slum to use their skills to earn income and be independent.

loans.use: To buy fabrics and threads and open another shop.

loans.name: Chhoun

texts.en: Chhoun S. Un, 28, is a professional tailor, making US$ 3 each day in Takeo province. She is married and has two children living at home to support. Her husband, Tang Rim, makes approximately US$ 2.50 every day, working in construction. Chhoun S. Un would like a loan of US$ 300 to purchase construction tools for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools for her husband.

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is 40 years old, married, and father of four, aged between 6 and 16 years, with three attending school.  He has been a mixed farmer for fifteen years.  He sells millet, maize, beans, tea, coffee and milk locally.

He has requested this loan of Kshs. 45,000 to buy a dairy cow. Proceeds from this loan will be used to feed the family. In five years he hopes to start a retail shop in Kenyenya market and have five good dairy cows.

The challenge he faces is lack of enough capital to enable him to run his farming business.  He is however thankful to Juhudi for the loan.

loans.use: buy a cow

loans.name: Walter

texts.en:
Walter O. O. is a 26 year-old man, married to Anastansia Kambua, with one child. He is in the motorcycle transportation business and also owns a tailoring business which is run by his wife in Changamwe. He has been in this business for the last two years. 

Walter has currently applied for his second loan with KADET to purchase more material for the tailoring business and also service his motorcycle. He plans to use the anticipated profits to help the needy and educate his child. His hope and dream for the future is to make his businesses successful.

loans.use: purchase taialoring materials and service his motocycle

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Mrs. Salma T. is from the village of Migpangi, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old, married to Celieto T. and blessed with 3 children of whom two are school-aged and the other is still an infant. To make a living, she is presently engaged in operating a sari-sari store. She is also receiving support from her husband who is a tricycle (motorcycle transport) driver. She’s been engaged in this kind of sari-sari store business for 3 years already. They’re earning an average amount of not less than Php 2,500 from this kind of business. 

Just this year, Salma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. As a newly recognized member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program, Salma is requesting a loan of Php 15,000 as her 1st loan which will be used as additional capital for her existing sari-sari store. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, making loan repayments, paying for her children’s education and possible business expansion.

 About PMPC:

 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her existing sari-sari (variety) store

location.town: P4 Migpangi, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental, Mindan

loans.name: Ngin

texts.en: Ngin S., 31, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She and her husband have a business selling silk cloth in the village. They have been doing this business since 2009 and are able to make about US$ 3 in profit each day. Ngin S. would like to take out a loan of US$ 600 to purchase more silk cloth for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more silk cloth for resale

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is married with three children between six and eight. He lives in Kwamuhila, Emali, which is along one of the major highways in Kenya. Simon has operated a Bodaboda (motorcycle) transport business for the last six years. His customers are mainly business people and travelers in the area.

Simon got to know about KADET through other members who were already in KADET and has never borrowed from another financial institution. He has currently applied for a loan to buy another motorcycle to increase his daily operation and income. With the two motorcycles, he can manage to cover a wider area.

loans.use: to buy another motorcycle

loans.name: Parn

texts.en: Parn S., 42, is married and lives with her husband (pictured here) in Takeo province. She and her husband are teachers, making US$2 each per day. The couple has four school-aged children. Parn would like a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Mauline

texts.en:
Mauline is 32 yrs old. She is married and the mother of four children aged between four and 12, all attending school. She has been practising mixed farming  for the last 12 years, producing tea, maize, milk and bananas which she sells locally. She has requested this loan of KES45,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow which she hopes will bring in enough income to assist in school fees, thus improving the family's living standard. In five years she hopes to establish a retail shop.

The challenge she faces is a poor road network in the area and delays in transportation.

loans.use: buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas N., 49, is married with two children living in Takeo province. She makes and sells palm sugar, typically earning US$1 profit a day, while her husband, pictured here, sells coconuts and palm fruit. On average, he earns US$2 per day. Meas N. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to transport coconuts and palm fruit to the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Pok

texts.en:
Pok S., 31, buys and sells yams, making 1 USD each day in the Takeo province. She is married and supports three children living at home. Her husband, Phan Soeurn, makes approximately 2 USD every day selling coconuts.

Pok S. would like a loan of 900 USD to purchase more coconuts to sell.

loans.use: To buy more coconuts to sell

loans.name: Kirehe Kwetungura Group A-Kihihi

texts.en:
B. William, 57, belongs to Kirehe Kwetungura group-Kihihi. He has been into tailoring for the last 20 years and mostly he has been selling school uniforms. Sensing that there was a ready market for clothes, William made a decision to start this business with capital from his farming business. William is happily married and has four kids with his wife. 

On a monthly basis, this tailoring business brings in 200,000 KES as profits. He says business expansion is next on his set objectives.  With this loan he says he is going to buy more clothes making material.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes making textile material

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en:
Andrew K. is a 32-year-old businessman who is married to Esther Wambui, 32, and they have been blessed with two children, ages six and two years old. He is the main breadwinner, but his wife, who is a tailor, also contributes to the family’s total income. Andrew runs a general store which he started nine years ago. 

Andrew has borrowed a loan of 50,000 KES, which is his fourth loan with KADET LTD after he successfully repaid his previous loans. He intends to use 15,000 KES to buy stock for the business, 20,000 KES to purchase two sewing machines for his wife's business, and the remaining amount he will use to pay for his tuition fee for a course he is pursuing. Andrew anticipates using the profits from his business to expand it, save for the schooling of his children, and also to build a house.

Andrew hopes to see his children get the best education possible within his means and build a good residential house for his family.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for the business

loans.name: Damba

texts.en:
Damba C. is 53 years old and lives with his adult son in his own fenced house in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. His son works as a private businessman.

In 2000 Damba opened a small shop where he sold food. Since then, he managed to expand his shop into a bigger grocery store. During years of successful operation, his earnings enabled him to provide for his three other children who are now married and live separately on their own.

Damba is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more products to sell at his shop. In the future, he plans to expand his grocery store into a supermarket. Damba is a hardworking and modest man and says, " My goal is to enlarge my house."

loans.use: To purchase more products for his store

loans.name: Kirehe Kwetungura Group B-Kihihi

texts.en: K. Jackline, 28, has been in the retailing business for the last three years in Kirehe-Kihihi. In her shop she sells a variety of general merchandise retail items such as sugar, salt and beans. Her clientele base mostly consists of local people within her village. What spawned her interest in this business was the fact that there was growing demand in her area for retail shops that sold items at affordable prices. Prior to this, her inclination was more into farming. On a monthly basis, this business brings her 120,000 KES as profits. With this loan, Jackline, who is a married mother with three kids, says she is going to procure more retail commodities for resale at her shop. She belongs to Kirehe Kwetungura group-Kihihi.

loans.use: To purchase more stock

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam C., 30, is married with two young children living at home in Takeo province. She sells wood, typically making 1 USD each day. Her husband, Kat Sal (pictured here), typically makes about 2 USD each day selling coconuts.

Sam C. would like a loan of 600 USD to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to transport coconuts.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike and trailer

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en: Loreta B. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 44 years old, married with four adult-aged children. To make a living, Loreta owns and operates a mini-restaurant. The main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals, especially Filipino delicacies like pork and chicken adobo, afritada, caldereta and sinigang na isda at baka to customers in the local community. In the picture you can see the actual business wherein there are lot of customers and her daughter who helps her in the business. Loreta has been engaged in her business for over 22 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2006, Loreta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Loreta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from HSPFI. She used this previous loan to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant. Loreta is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which she will invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the seventh taken out by Loreta from HSPFI. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business.

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Ny A., 44, is a professional handicrafts decorator, making US$1 each day in the Takeo province. She is married and has five children. Her husband, Phan Proek, makes approximately US$2 every day, selling coconuts.

Ny A. would like a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to transport coconuts.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Tep

texts.en:
Tep S., 51, is married with three children living at home in the Takeo province. She is a good housewife doing housework and cooking food for her family members. Her husband is a security guard, typically making US$3 every day. This family is also supported by two of the children working in construction.

Tep S. would like to take out a loan of US$1200 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Hurelhuyag

texts.en:
Hurelhuyag T. is 45 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Uvs province, Mongolia.  He and his family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent home, in the  yard of the organization where he works as a guard. The family lost their home to a fire in 2008 but the couple is working very hard to establish their home again. His wife works as a cleaner in a local grocery shop.

Hurelhuyag has been making wooden ger frames such as walls, ceilings, etc., for the past 20 years and has gained a lot of experience as a craftsman. He usually produces wooden ger frames with 5, 6, or 8 walls according to his customers' orders. Last summer, he made 20 ger frames. His son helps him to produce his wooden products.

 After many years of owing this business, he has built up a stable and successful operation and his earnings have enabled him to pay his daughter's tuition fees. In the future, as he continues support his family, he hopes to grow his business further by producing not only ger frames but also ger furniture. 

Hurelhuyag is a hardworking man and says, "I try to live well without falling into the difficulties and barriers of life." He is requesting a 450,000 MNT loan to purchase more wood and supplies for his ger frame-making business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and supplies

loans.name: Mrs. Mao Soem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of ten people who live in Ta Sou village in Takeo province. All of the members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family's lives. 

Mrs. Mao S., 55, is the village bank president and has been selected by the other members. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to grow both rice and vegetable to sell to support her family. Although she tries to work a lot, she earns little money. So to improve her family's lives, Mrs. Mao Some is seeking for a loan to add more money in purchasing a cow for breeding to start a new business. She is a widow with two children, one of whom is a laborer and the other is a farmer.

loans.use: To add more money to buy a cow

loans.name: Burambira Development Group A-Kihihi

texts.en:
K. Joseph, 60, is still agile and dynamic at his twilight age. He has been bringing all of his products to bear in his food-selling business for the past 20 years at the Burambira trading center, Kihihi. 

He says he set forth in this trade using savings from selling various cash crops had the lowest prices, a business that his community highly partook in. The business generates weekly profits of 40,000 shillings for Joseph, who is happily married with four kids. He says that with this loan, he will procure more crops to resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more crops such for resell

loans.name: Tout

texts.en: Tout S., 48, a married mother of four children, grows mushrooms, making US$1 each day in Takeo Province.  Her husband works in construction, earning US$3 a day to help support the family. One of the children works in construction, and three are in school. Tout would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to transport mushrooms to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Burambira Development Group B-Kihihi

texts.en: M. Privata, 46, has been operating his retail shop for a decade in the Burambira trading center named Kihihi. Privata, a happily married father of six, belongs to Burambira Development Group, Kihihi. He is married and borrowed money from a local savings and credit group to begin this business. His shop sells a variety of general merchandise items that are in high demand with most of his clients. His business brings in weekly profits of 70,000 shillings. With this loan he says he is looking at purchasing more retail commodities such as sugar, maize flour, and rice to resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more retail commodities for resell

loans.name: Teolijean

texts.en:
Teolijean L., from the village of Hinigdaan, El Salvador City, Misamis Oriental, is 26 years old and married. To make a living, Teolijean owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling daily-use products such as pollard, rice and corn bran and also retails gasoline per liter in the local community. Additionally, she operates a retail store selling snack foods and breads. Teolijean has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Teolijean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional products to buy and sell, she is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP to use as working capital and to purchase additional inventory for sale. This will be Teolijean's fourth loan from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Working capital and to purchase additional inventory for sale

loans.name: Lhagva

texts.en:
Lhagva B. is 53 years old and lives with her husband and son in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent and fence, in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband is currently unemployed and helps with Lhagva's business. Her son works in a drinking water manufacturing company and plans to establish his own pure water producing factory and has started to purchase the necessary equipment in order to open it. 

 Lhagva operates a tailoring business out of her home. She has been making a variety of traditional clothes since 2000 and has since gained a lot of experience as a seamstress. She usually sells her products to the traditional clothes sellers in Narantuul market, the largest and most important market in the city. With her business earnings, she has invested her son's future business by helping him to purchase some tools and equipment. 

In the future, she plans to have her own workplace where she will sew a variety of traditional clothes for her customers. Lhagva is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase materials to make "deel"s.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make "deel" (traditional Mongolian coats)

loans.name: Mrs. Yon Khom Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has eight members fR. the Trapeang Angk village in Takeo province, who each will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Yon K. is the village bank president, and has been selected by the other members. She and her husband, Mr. Gnorn Ouch, are farmers who own a plot of land more than one hectacres to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Mr. Gnorn Ouch is alS. a palm juice collector who earns some money fR. selling palm sugar. Although they all try to work hard, they earn little money. S. to improve their family living, Mrs. Yon K. is applying for a loan to buy three piglets to breed to start a new business. She is a mother of five children, two of whom are employed in garment factory, one a laborer at Thailand, and the others are studying in local public school.

loans.use: To buy three piglets for breeding

loans.name: Naranbaatar

texts.en:
Naranbaatar T. is 33 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family all live together in their 'ger' (Mongolian nomadic housing tent). His two oldest children, ages 13 and 11, both attend secondary school and one of his daughters, age 5, is in kindergarten while his youngest daughter stays at home. His wife works as a salesperson in a local shop to supplement her family's income, and Naranbaatar owns his own car and is a taxi driver in his town. 

He began his business in 2006 after working and living as a herdsman in the countryside. After years of successful business operation, he was able to purchase a plot of land and fence for his family. For the future, he is planning to build a winter house in his yard and improve his car so that he can continue to earn a living. He is requesting a 650,000 MNT loan in order to purchase construction materials and  necessary parts for his car.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 44 years old, married, and a father of five, aged between 3 and 12 years, with four attending school.  He has been in mixed farming for fifteen years.  He sells maize, beans, bananas, and milk locally.
 
With the loan of Kshs. 45,000= he will buy a cow which will improve the living standard of the family in terms of food and wealth.  In five years he aspires to expand his herd of dairy cows to five and start a posho (cornmeal) mill business.

The challenge he faces is lack of enough capital for farming and harsh weather conditions which affect crop production.  He thanks Juhudi for the financial services.

loans.use: buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora P. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 53 years old. Flora is widowed and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Flora owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes  from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, junk foods, canned goods, biscuits, breads, & detergents in the local community. Flora has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Flora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products for sale. Flora is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory for sale and as working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Flora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory for sale and as working capital

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas S. is 28 years old and is the mother of four children, all of whom are single and live at home. Meas S. has one small shop in the busy market, and she sells a few goods such as snack products, plastic products, and groceries items. She earns an income of approximately $5.35 per day to help support her family’s daily expenses. Her husband is a police officer and has a regular monthly salary. Meas S. has been living with her mother since before she married, and now she wishes to live in her own house with her husband and children. Because she does not have enough money saved, she is asking for a loan in order to buy a small piece of land on which she may build her new house.

loans.use: To buy a small piece of land for a family home.

loans.name: Sarorng's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarorng C. is the group leader who is 25 years old and has been selected by five members who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family living. The members are all from the Trapeang Thlan village in the Takeo province. 

She is a beef and fish seller in the local village where she is able to earn large profits to support her family. She is also a farmer who owns a plot of land more than one hectacre to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sam Art Im, is a construction worker. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. So to improve production, Mrs. Sarorng C. is asking for a loan to buy more beef to sell. She is a mother of two children whom all are too small to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more beef to sell

loans.name: Kazinga Development Group-Kihihi

texts.en: B. Benon, 41, belongs to the Kazinga Development group-Kihihi. He is married with three kids and for six years he has been running a food-selling business in the Kihihi Market. Primarily he has sold rice and coffee. To start up in this business, he relied on his savings given the fact that he is a secondary school teacher. Benon says that hard work and the good chord he has struck with his clients have gotten him where he is today. He still teaches and earns a salary. His business earns a profit of 70,000 shillings weekly. With this loan he says he is going to procure more bags of the aforementioned food to resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more of more bags of rice and coffee for resell

loans.name: Jelly

texts.en:
Jelly D. C. is 37 years old, married and has three school-aged children. She is from the village of Hinigdaan in the municipality of Manolo Fortich, a part of Bukidnon province on the northern Mindanao islands. Jelly plants, harvests and sells rice and corn. She also makes and sells Filipino delicacies like rice cakes and cassava cakes. Jelly has been in business for over ten years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jelly joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Jelly successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and starts to raise. Jelly is requesting a new loan, her third from HSPFI, of 10,000 PHP that will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Ulziit

texts.en:
Ulziit D. is 33 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Uvs province, Mongolia. She works as a cook in a five-star restaurant to supplement her family's income. Ulziit and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her daughter, age 13, attends a local secondary school while her husband has been operating a meat trading business since 2003 to support the family. After years of success in the business, her husband was able to purchase a plot of land and fence for his family’s ger.

In 2008, in addition to his meat business, Ulziit’s husband decided to open a retail clothing business out of a rented stall at the local market. Using their business profits, they also purchased and own a small grocery shop next to their home. Her husband plans to continue operating his meat business during the winter when it is very profitable.

Since operating their businesses, their quality of life has been improving year by year. Ulziit is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan for their meat trading business. She hopes to continue being successful and to grow her businesses.

loans.use: For capital for their meat business

loans.name: Vet's Group

texts.en:
This village loan is made up of nine people. They are located in the Preaek Reang village in the Kandal province. This village loan, selected Mrs. Vet S. L., a 31-year-old married woman, as the village bank president. The members of this village will use their money for different purposes.

Mrs. Vet S. L. is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of rice field where she cultivates rice. To support this farming, she would like to ask for a loan to buy rice seeds, fertilizer and gasoline to grow rice. Aside from farming, she also raises fish and sells grocery at home. With her businesses, she is able to earn a little income to support her famiL.. Her husband, Mr. Sot Sien, 31, works as a fisherman and also helps his wife with her current careers.

This couple has a child who is three years old.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds, fertilizer and gasoline to grow rice.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou C. is 43 years old, married and has seven school-aged children. She is from the village of Tumpagon, a part of Cagayan de Oro City, Misamis Oriental province on the Mindanao islands. Marilou runs a tailoring business providing general alterations and sewing curtains, pillow cases, etc. for local community members. Marilou has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to invest in expanding her business. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional fabric and materials. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabric and materials

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Timothy

texts.en:
Peter is 51 years old. He is married and the father of four children between the ages of 8 and 22. They are all attending school. He has been a farmer for twenty years. He sells maize, beans, tea, millet and milk locally.

He has requested this loan of 45,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow, which will help improve his family's living standards in terms of both food and income. In five years he aspires to start up a large retail shop business and have a posho mill.

The challenge he is facing is that market prices for farm produce are low and there is not enough financing available to purchase farming inputs like fertilizers, which affects his crop production. He is thankful to Juhudi for the loan and hopes to get another.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Mrs. Him Em Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has ten people who live in the Ta Sou village in the Takeo province. Mrs. Him E., 35, has been selected by the other members to be the village bank president. Each member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Him E. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to grow rice to sell to support her family. She is also a recycled goods seller who is able to earn some income to support her family. Though she tries to work hard, she earns a little money. So to improve her family's lives, Mrs. Him E. is seeking a loan to add more money to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. She is a widow with four children, three of whom are enrolled in local school while the youngest one is four years old.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine I. is from the town of Trinidad. She is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine sells fruits and vegetables. Josephine earns approximately 3,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from her business.

In 2010, Josephine joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fruits and vegetables to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase additional fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Myraflor

texts.en: Myraflor T. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 23 years old. Myraflor is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Myraflor makes and sells chicken and pork barbecue. Myraflor has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Myraflor joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myraflor has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients to make and sell. Myraflor is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the third loan taken out by Myraflor from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Oeun's Group

texts.en:
This village loan is made up of nine people; the members live in the Preaek Reang village in the Kandal province. This village loan selected Mrs. Oeun S., 42, as the village bank president. The members of this loan will use their portions of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Oeun S. and her husband, Mr. Prum Nat, are farmers who own a 1.20-hectare of land to cultivate rice and different vegetables for a living. With this farming, they do not have enough money to grow their crops. Thus, Mrs. Oeun S. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer and gasoline to cultivate rice. Beside farming, Mr. Prum Nat, is also a fisherman in the local village.

This couple has four children: two are seamstresses in a garment factory and the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer and gasoline to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 56 years old. She is a widowed mother of nine children aged between 23 and 36 years. One of her children is attending school. She is a mixed farmer who sells maize, sorghum, tea, coffee and milk locally.

She has requested this loan of 45,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow. Proceeds from this loan will help pay fees for the child in university. 

In five years, she aspires to have a passenger transport vehicle for business. The challenges she faces are irregularities in casual laborers' turnover on the farm, lack of enough capital to invest in other farming practices and the establishment of a fish pond. However, she thanks Juhudi for the financial service.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Ibambiro Tukwatanise Group-Kihihi

texts.en: High-spirited 32-year-old T. Patrick began his retail shop business a decade ago in the Vanema trading center in Kihihi. It is a general merchandise shop that sells an array of different commodities such as salt, sugar and  maize flour. This enterprise, which was begun by using funding from selling a goat, makes 100,000 shillings for this father of five. Farming, primarily poultry, is also another activity from which he earns some additional income. With this loan he says he is purchase more commodities to resell at his shop.

loans.use: The purchase of more commodities for resell

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario N. is from the village of Puntabon, Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 45 years old. Rosario is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosario owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling Filipino snack delicacies like suman (rice cake) and maruya (banana fritters) in the local community. Rosario has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rosario joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosario is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Rosario from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

location.town: Puntabon, Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza B. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 34 years old. Analiza is married and has 2 children aged 7 and 8. To make a living, Analiza owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fruits and daily use products. Analiza has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Analiza joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analiza is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Analiza from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the school fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Ol's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of six members, who are from the Preaek Reang village in the Kandal province. Mrs. Ol S., 42, is as the group leader who was selected by the members of this group. Each member hopes to increase their income to support their family with these loans. 

Mrs. Ol S. and her husband, Mr. Pheng Kheang, are farmers who own a rice field plot at which they cultivate rice for a living. They lack some money to support this farming. Thus, Mrs. Ol S. would like to ask for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer and gasoline to cultivate rice. Aside from farming, Mr. Pheng Kheang is also a fisherman who is able to earn a little income to support his family. 

This spouse has five children, one who helps their father fishing, three who attend in the local school, and the last one who is five years old and not in school yet.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer and gasoline to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 38 years old and married. She has five children, from the ages of 14 to 4 years, who are all in school.

She has been in the farming business for seven years and sells products such as maize, beans, cabbage, and milk to the local market.

She has requested a loan for 31,200 KES through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She hopes that the loan will improve life for her family, allowing them to get enough milk for home consumption as well as enough milk for selling, to help meet their basic needs.

In the next five years, Beatrice hopes to own four dairy cows and a chuff cutter to make feeding of her livestock easier. She hopes to become the main milk supplier in the local market.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Kanungu Kwetungura-Kihihi Group

texts.en: B. Girino, 50, is strong-willed and never one who loses sight of his goals and values. He has been overseeing the running of his business selling spare parts along Katate Road in Kihihi for 25 years. At his business premises, his workers carry out machine repairs and they also sell spare parts for him. His side coffee-selling business was instrumental in terms of building a financial base strong enough for him to venture into his current business. He has not dispensed of the coffee-selling business, notwithstanding the fact that he now gives more priority to his garage business. Aside from the two businesses, he operates two additional business: the selling of cows and bananas. His business generates 580,000 shillings monthly. Girino belongs to the Kanungu Kwetungura group of Kihihi and with this loan, he says he wants to buy more spare parts for resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more spare parts for resell.

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
Narcisa C. is from the village of Puntabon, Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 45 years old. Narcisa is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Narcisa owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from dealing and selling medicinal or therapeutic coffee, tea and food supplements from LINGZHI products in the local community. Narcisa has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Narcisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Narcisa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory for sale and working capital. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Narcisa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory for sale and working capital.

location.town: Puntabon, Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 72 years old, widowed and mother of seven aged between 32-52 yrs. She has been practising mixed farming for over 30 years. She produces maize, tea, coffee, sugarcane, and milk, which she sells locally. She has one employee. 

She has requested this loan of Kshs. 45,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow. This loan will earn the family extra income and thus they will be able to make some investments. In five years she aspires to have four dairy cows.

The challenge she faces is unreliable employees and lack of enough finance to continue farming practices in both dairy and crop production.  She is thankful to Juhudi and hopes for more loans.

loans.use: To buy a cow.

loans.name: Sean

texts.en: Sean T. has spent her life cultivating crops. This is a skill she learned from her grandparents when she was young. She is now married and has four children, and most of them are not enrolled in school yet, because they are so young. Her husband works in the farm fields frequently alongside her. Sean T. is able to plant crops at least twice a year. She is able to plant crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. Because her farm is outside of a watering system, Sean T. would like a loan to buy a pumping machine for irrigation. She proposes to use the remainder of loan to do a dry-season rice-field.

loans.use: To buy a pumping machine for irrigation, and to do a dry-season rice-field.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Chheng's Group

texts.en:
Eight members form this village loan; they are from the Traeuy Troeng village in the Kandal province. This village loan selected Mrs. Chheng K., 53, as the village bank president. With the loans, they hope to increase their income to improve their familys' living. 

Mrs. Chheng K. is a farmer who owns a rice field plot to cultivate rice for a living. She does not have enough farming supplies to cultivate rice. So she would like to ask for a loan to purchase a water machine and rice seed to do so. Her husband, Mr. Chhem Ol, 53, works as a fisherman, and also helps in his wife's farming activity.

This couple has four children, three of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory and another who is attending in the local school.

loans.use: To purchase a water machine and rice seed to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah has been doing mixed farming for 2 years, producing milk and selling to the local market. She has employed 2 farmhands.

She has applied for this 2nd loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo having acquired and fully paid the first one of 17,000, which enabled her to venture into the poultry business. She has decided to diversify her business in order to cope with high price fluctuations in the market. Such a consistent income she says will ensure the schooling of her 3 children.

She gives compliments to Juhudi Kilimo for improvement in service delivery, especially timely disbursement of cheques, saying, "cheque delay has become a thing of the past".

loans.use: To start a poultry project.

loans.name: Kitookye Trading Center Society-Kihihi Group

texts.en:
T. Justus, 48, is a married father of four who runs a produce-selling business in the Kitookye trading center of Kihihi. He mostly sells beans, peas and coffee. He started this business eight years ago with savings from his farming business. Justus comes across as a down-to-earth, strong-willed and cooperative gentleman. 

Clients of his business vary from hotel owners, housewives, to retailers. Justus says he still runs his farming business given the fact that it is too a dependable means of livelihood in Uganda. Justus says he has managed to give all of his children an education using profits from both these businesses. The produce-selling enterprise generates 50,000 shillings each week for him. With this loan he says he is going to buy more cash crops like millet, maize and rice to resell. He is affiliated with the Kitookye Trading Center Society Group.

loans.use: The purchase of more cash crops such as millet, maize and rice for resell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. is from the village of Puntabon, Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 34 years old. Elizabeth is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, junk foods & breads in the local community. She is also engaged in providing billiard games where the customer pays for every game finished. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Elizabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to buy and sell.

location.town: Puntabon, Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita G. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 54 years old. Juanita is married and has 4 children. To make a living, Juanita owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling vegetables and fruits like bananas. Juanita wishes for her business to grow. She hopes to earn a better income.

Juanita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juanita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Juanita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Bo's Group

texts.en:
Nine members forms this village loan; they are all located in the Traeuy Troeng village in the Kandal province. The members of this village loan selected Mrs. Bo C., a 26-year-old married woman, as the village bank president. Each member of this village loan will use their portions of the loan to support a different purpose. 

Mrs. Bo C. is a farmer who owns a one-hectare rice field to cultivate rice. She also earns her living by knitting. Her husband, Mr. Chea Sarorn, is an iron welder. With their businesses, they still earn less income to support the family. In order to increase their income to improve the family's condition, Mrs. Bo C. would like to ask for a loan to buy clothes for selling, and with the rest of the loan she would like to buy pigs for breeding.

This couple has two children who are just one year old and five years old.

loans.use: To buy clothes for selling

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo S. is from the village of Puntabon, Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 31 years old. Danilo is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Danilo owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle, or habal-habal, services to local community members. Danilo has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Danilo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Danilo is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the motorcycle. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Danilo from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tools needed for maintenance of the motorcycle.

location.town: Puntabon, Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Chamroeun's Group

texts.en:
Nine members form this village loan; the members are from the Traeuy Troeng village in the Kandal province. This village loan selected Mrs. Chamroeun M., 51, as the village bank president. Each member of this village will use their portions of the loan to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Chamroeun M. is a farmer who owns two-hectares of rice fields to cultivate rice for a living. She does not have enough money to cultivate her farming. So she decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer and gasoline to grow rice. Her husband, Mr. Chou Au, 53 years old, works as ice cream seller who is able to earn a little income to support his family. 

They have seven children, one who is an iron welder, two are seamstresses in the garment factory, and the others are students who also help their mother in farming.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer and gasoline to grow rice.

loans.name: Ma. Viola

texts.en:
Ma. Viola M. is from the village of Barangay 5, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 32 years old. Ma. Viola is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Viola owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, junk foods, and spices like garlic and onions, in the local community. Ma. Viola has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ma. Viola joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Viola is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Ma. Viola from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to buy and sell.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 26-year-old single woman from Lebanon. She lives with her mother, two brothers and one sister. She has been working as a farmer for the past 8 years and in 2008, she started working independently on her father’s land raising cattle. She produces dairy products such as milk, yogurt, etc.  She is thankful for her business income; she cooperates with her brothers to cover the household expenses.

 Today, she is requesting to borrow US$ 1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase fertilizers and feed for the cattle to give a good quality of products for the coming season, knowing that in Lebanon the majority of housewives prepare home products to use all through the year. In the future, she is planning to purchase more cattle in order to expand her business.

loans.use: purchase fertilizers and feed for the cattle

loans.name: Veng's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people. They are located in the Traeuy Troeng village in the Kandal province. Mrs. Veng K., 50 years old, was selected as the group leader by the members of this group loan. The members of this group hope that they will increase income to improve the family's lives with this loan. 

Mrs. Veng K. is a farmer who owns a plot of rice field where she cultivates rice for a living, but she does not have enough money to do so. She would like to ask for a loan to buy rice seeds, fertilizers and pesticides to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Moeung Sombath, is a motorcycle taxi driver who is able to earn some income to support his family. 

This couple has a child who is a iron welder.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds, fertilizers and pesticides to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Moeun

texts.en: Moeun S. is a married woman who lives in the province of Kompong Cham. She and her husband currently live with her two children, two of whom are single, and learning in school. To earn a living, Moeun S. cultivates a crop and has been farming since 2005. Moeun S. has a large farmland and she and her husband can't plow it yet because her family has only two members who can plow. To solve this situation, Moeun S. would like a loan to hire machine for plowing her farmland and to hire a domestic laborer to harvest the rest of her farmland.

loans.use: To hire machine for plowing her farmland and to hire a domestic laborer to harvest the rest of her farmland.

loans.name: Estrella's Group

texts.en:
Estrella A. is from the village of Bugallon, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 53 years old. Estrella is the group leader of a 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Estrella is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Estrella owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector selling agricultural supplies. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling animal feed and mash to local farmers. Estrella has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Estrella joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrella has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Estrella is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Estrella from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen C. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 47 years old. Helen is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Helen owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, junk foods, and also vegetables like string beans, in the local community. She also deals in NATASHA personal products. Helen has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Helen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Helen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to buy and sell.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 48 years old, married, and the mother of nine aged between 10-30 years old, with seven attending school. For thirty years she has been in dairy farming and sells her milk locally. She also buys milk from other farmers and sells by transporting it by donkey.  She has one employee.

She has applied for this loan of 45,000KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow, which will improve the milk production, thus increasing income. 
The challenges she experiences is sourcing for a good cow and lack of clean water. She is happy with Juhudi for its easy loan advances.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Vahram

texts.en:
Vahram Aklunc is married with three children. The family lives with Vahram’s parents, and are all engaged in agriculture for about 10 years, which gives the family a source of income.

Vahram has done his best to fill his children’s rural childhood with happiness.  Now, realizing the great role of education, Vahram would like to start saving for a good education for his children in future. Vahram has applied for the loan to purchase livestock to increase the family’s income.

loans.use: puchasing livestock

loans.name: Seom's Group

texts.en:
This village loan is comprised of eleven people. They are located in the Traeuy Troeng village in the Kandal province. This village loan selected Mrs. Seom C., a 44-year-old married woman, as the village bank president. Each member of this village will use their portions of the loan to support a different purpose. 

Mrs. Seom C. and her husband, Mr. Sam Sol, are farmers who own a two-hectare of land to cultivate rice for a living. Aside from farming, Mrs. Seom C. also sells groceries in the local village. In order to increase income to improve the family condition, Mrs. Seom C. wants to expand it. So she would like to ask for a loan to buy grocery to enlarge her business activities. 

This spouse has four children, one of whom is electrician and the others are students who also help their parents with farming.

loans.use: To buy grocery to enlarge her business activities.

loans.name: Mutai

texts.en:
Mutai is 30 years old, married, and father of three aged between 1-5 years old, with one attending school. He has been a mixed farmer for seven years. His products are pineapples, tea, and milk which he sells locally. He also earns income extra income from a shop he operates.

He has requested this loan of Kshs. 40,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow. In five years he wants to have a modern dairy unit for his animals.

The challenge he faces is diseases in dairy farming.  He is thankful to Juhudi for the support and hopes it continues in future.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina E. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 32 years old. Rosalina is married and has 2 children aged 14 and 17. To make a living, Rosalina owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. She sells milk, sugar and other products.

Rosalina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosalina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Peri

texts.en: Peri M. lives with her mother, brother and sister. Being the oldest among the children, after Peri’s father passed away, Peri started her business to support the family. Peri’s brother is in the Army and her sister is a student. Peri’s mother has helped in running her clothing and linen business since 2008. Peri has succeeded in having a good clientele. For the upcoming New Year and Christmas season Peri needs to make new orders, for which she has applied for the loan.

loans.use: stocking up on Christmas and New Year orders

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella T. is from the village of Dalirig, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 57 years old. Estrella is widowed and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Estrella owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling Filipino delicacy meats, like chicken halang-halang and adobong pork, for the local community. Estrella has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Estrella joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrella is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Estrella from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Alisher

texts.ru: Аберов Алишер проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 21 год. Женат. Детей не имеет. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Алишер имеет среднее образование. Вместе с отцом занимается строительными работами по найму. Кроме того занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где выращивает овощи. В этой области уже 5 лет. Целью кредита является закуп минеральных удобрений и солярки для трактора.
texts.en: Alisher A. lives in Shahrituz.  He is 21 years old, married, and has no children.  His wife is a housewife.  Alisher has a secondary education.  He and his father work as day laborers in construction.  Additionally, he works in agriculture.  At his house he has a plot where he grows vegetables. He has been doing this for five years. He is taking out a loan to buy mineral fertilizers and diesel for his tractor.

loans.use: buying mineral fertilizers and diesel

loans.name: Eduard

texts.en:
Eduard J. is married with three children and lives with his parents. One of his children is serving in the army and another helps Eduard in running his business.
Eduard has been trading in glassware and crockery since 1995. During the last 15 years of hard work, Eduard has been able to provide his family’s main income, invest in both his business and his children’s education, and meet general family costs. Eduard needs to stock up for the holiday season, and has therefore applied to Kiva partner, SEF, for a loan.

loans.use: To purchase holiday season stock

loans.name: Steve

texts.en:
Steve G. is from the village of San Isidro, Talakag, Bukidnon. He is 33 years old. Steve is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Steve owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle, or habal-habal, services to local community members. Steve has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Steve joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Steve is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the motorcycle. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Steve from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the motorcycle.

loans.name: Dou Tha's Group

texts.en:
This village loan is made up of 15 members located in Traeuy Troeng village in Kandal province. The group selected Mrs. Dou T., a 49-year-old married woman, as the village bank president. Each member of this group loan will use their portion of the loan to support a different purpose.
Mrs. Dou T. is a farmer who rents some land to cultivate rice for a living. She does not have enough money to grow rice and is therefore requesting a loan to buy rice seed and to hire laborers to plow her farm. Her husband, Mr. K. S., is a farm laborer and also helps in his wife's farming. This couple has five children: one is a mechanic, one a knitter and the other three are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and hire laborers to plow her farm

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson W. is 30 years old and lives in the town of Kitale in western Kenya. He is married with three children, aged nine, five and two.

Nelson has been in the farming business for ten years and sells products such as maize, tomatoes, cabbage, and milk at a local market. He is requesting a loan of 52,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow.
