With the expected increase in income, Nelson hopes to be able to better support his family. Five years from now, he hopes to have expanded his business and own at least five dairy cows.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en:
Teopista B. is married and has four children, three of whom are in school. She lives in the Ndeeba neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. Teopista lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and food for the family.

Teopista sells fruits and vegetables. She has been in business for less than one year, working seven days a week. She sells her produce at the market.

Teopista has requested a loan of 700,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of tomatoes, oranges, green peppers, fresh cow peas and onions. Her main business challenges include transportation and seasonal changes.

Teopista’s goal is to buy land upon which to grow these vegetables herself.

loans.use: To buy more produce to sell

loans.name: Merlie

texts.en:
Merlie A. is 40 years old, married and has six school-aged children. She is from the village of Hinigdaan, a part of El Salvador City within Misamis Oriental province in the Mindanao islands. Merlie runs a family member's sari-sari (variety) shop from which she buys and sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and snacks to the local community. Merlie has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Merlie joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Merlie is requesting her first loan from HSPFI of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to buy and sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 21-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his brother. He has been working as a home painter from the past 6 years and in 2007, he started working independently on a freelance basis. He takes on small projects to earn income and he cooperates with his brother to pay the expenses of the home, electricity, food, etc.  Today, he is requesting to borrow US$ 1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional tools and external scaffolding for his newest project. In the future, he is planning to take on bigger projects and work with construction entrepreneurs to expand his business level.

loans.use: to purchase additional tools and external scaffolding for his newest project

loans.name: Mayi

texts.en:
Mayi K. lives in the Makerere Kikoni neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school.  

Mayi has a business selling charcoal. She has been in this business for four years and she works seven days out of every week. Mayi sells her products from home, by means of retail.   

Mayi has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. She also generates additional income through cooked food vending.

The main business challenges for Mayi include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van. 

Mayi lives in a home that she owns and she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Angelina's Group

texts.en:
Angelina M., from the village of Brgy. Dadap, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya, is the 42-year-old group leader of an 11-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Angelina, who is married and has two school-aged children, owns and operates a specialized retail store selling personal products such as glasses and watches in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Angelina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be Angelina's second loan from ASKI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch P. is 38-year-old married woman who lives in Phnom Penh City of Cambodia. (Her husband appears in the photo.) Touch P. has a piece of land that she inherited from her grandmother. She grows different kinds of crops on this land, such as cabbages, cucumbers and morning glories, which she will sell to buyers every two or three months when the plants mature. 

Her husband has grown these crops with her. The couple has four school-aged children. 

Touch P. is concerned that her house is not comfortable because the hedge of the house is broken and it needs to be repaired. So she would like to request a loan to repair the hedge of her house.

loans.use: To repair the hedge of her house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Daler

texts.ru: Хакимов Далер проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 24 года. Женат. Имеет двоих детей. Образование среднее. Более 6 лет занимается торговлей. Имеет магазин, где продает детские игрушки, коляски и ходунки. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: Daler H. lives in Shahrituz.  He is 24 years old, married, and has two children.  He has a secondary education. He has been working in sales for more than six years.  He has a shop where he sells children's toys, strollers, and walkers. He is taking out a loan to increase his sales.

loans.use: Increasing sales

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 48-year-old married man and the father of four children from Lebanon. For the past few years, he has made his living as a professional driver. He operates a van service for customers in his village as well as neighboring towns. His main route is between his town and its surroundings. He has obtained a first Kiva loan and he is thankful for it. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow US$ 800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l.  to perform maintenance work on his van in addition to changing its tires. These improvements will enable him to provide his service to more passengers.  In the future, he is planning to purchase a second van to increase his business level and therefore his family's income.

loans.use: to perform maintenance work on his van in addition to changing its tires

loans.name: Burulcha Bakoeva's Group

texts.en:
Burulcha B. is the leader of this group. Burulcha is a resident of Tashkomur. She is 23 years old and married. Her husband earns a living by selling cars. Together they bring up two preschool sons (under seven). A year ago, with an initial investment of 50,000 KGS, Burulcha started to sell women’s clothing. In this way she makes 10,000 KGS per month. She hopes to obtain this loan because she needs money to purchase winter clothes for resale. In the future she wants to expand her business and her dream is to open her own store.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase winter clothes for resale

loans.name: Silvia

texts.en: Silvia P. is 26 years old and married to a boda-boda operator. She has one child, who does not go to school. Silvia is currently in the business of selling bread and groundnut paste. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To stock more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith N. lives in the Ndeeba neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of her mother. Judith lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and feeding the family.
Judith has a business selling alcohol in a retail shop. She has been in this business for over ten years, and works seven days a week. Judith has requested a loan of 600,000 UGX from Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, to buy more crates of beer, soda and jerrycans of local gin. Her main business challenges are thieves and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a beer depot.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer, soda and jerrycans of local gin

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary P.  is currently in the business of selling onions, cooking oil, simsim (sesame) and groundnuts. She is requesting a loan to stock more onions and groundnuts to sell. Mary is 39 years old and married to a carpenter. She has 2 children, who both attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: Stock more onions and groundnuts to sell

loans.name: Eshbay

texts.ru: Субанов Эшбай проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 57 лет. Женат. Имеет 9 детей. Дети находятся на заработках в России. Сам Эшбай имеет среднее образование. Занимается растениеводством. Имеет земельный участок, где выращивает овощи и сажает деревья. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 18 лет. Целью кредита является закуп минеральных удобрений.
texts.en: Eshbay S. lives in Shahrituz.  He is 57 years old, married, and has nine children.  His children are working in Russia. Eshbay has a secondary education. He works in agriculture.  He has a plot of land where he grows vegetables and plants trees.  He has been doing this work for eighteen years. He is using this loan to buy mineral fertilizers.

loans.use: Buying mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Nazira's Group

texts.en:
When she was 46, Nazira D. lost her husband and became a widow. She has 3 children who claim care and proper upbringing. The eldest daughter is temporarily unemployed, one son is a university student and the youngest son is a schoolboy.

In 1994, Nazira began her career by working as a canteen cook, and she came to the conclusion of starting her own business. Today she offers a public catering service in the Tashkomur canteen. Business profits have made it possible for her to obtain a car. However, in order to make more profit, her business requires development. That’s why Nazira has applied for a loan: she wants to purchase equipment for cooking and improve the canteen’s interior. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase equipment for cooking

loans.name: You

texts.en:
You S. is a low-income person living in Phnom Penh. She and her husband are fish sellers in the local market. This couple earns a profit on average of $10 per day. Every day in the late morning, they go to a place where fishermen sell fish in bulk. Then they hurry to bring the fish to the busy market to sell it for retail prices.

You S. has only one child, who attends school. You S. is also facing difficulties commuting to the market to sell her fish because her vehicle is usually broken. Therefore, You S. is applying for some funds from Kiva to add to her savings in order to purchase a new motorcycle for driving to the market to sell fish.

loans.use: to purchase a new motorcycle for driving to the market to sell fish

loans.name: Batzaya

texts.en: Batzaya B. is 27 years old and lives with his wife and son in the Hovd province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. He has been operating a transportation business, using his own big truck, since 2010. He began his business in 2010 after working as a driver in the military army. After many years of owning this business, he has gained much experience. For the future, he is planning to improve his truck. Batzaya is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more coal to sell.

loans.use: to purchase more coal

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary S. is currently in the business of selling secondhand clothes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more clothes to sell. Mary is 30 years old and married; her husband is a driver. She has 3 children, who all attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, Mary hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: to stock more clothes to sell

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy N. lives in the Ndeeba neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has four children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (her old parents). Lucy has a business selling spare parts. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Lucy sells her products in a shop, by means of retail. The main business challenges for Lucy include thieves and transportation.

Lucy has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of spare parts. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start importing spare parts from Dubai. Lucy lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and feeding the family.

Here is Lucy in a black t-shirt, pictured at the centre meeting with her group mates.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of  spare parts.

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en: B. Lawrence is an individual client from Kihihi. He is 49 years old and married with four children aged between three and thirteen. He is a salary earner and is requesting a loan to pay his children’s school fees since he cannot draw his salary to clear the school dues. Lawrence is also involved in agriculture – he grows food crops for sale on a small scale and he hopes to expand this further in future.

loans.use: To pay his children's school dues

loans.name: Bayarmaa

texts.en:
Bayarmaa T. is a 46 years old single mother who lives with her adult son in Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. She and her son live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her only son operates a computer service and photographing business which was started in August 2009, in a rented space to supplement their family income. Bayarmaa started her own business after graduating from vocational training majoring as a hairdresser and photographer in 1984. She has been operating her business for many years and has much experience. In addition, she also works as a servant in the police department of the province to increase her earnings.

Since 2009, she started to rent a space where she operates her hair salon. For the future, she is planning to not only expand and improve her business but also her son's business.

Bayarmaa is a talkative and open minded woman and says, "I want to have my own comfortable work place."  She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase professional photo camera and color printer for her son's business.

loans.use: To purchase a professional photo camera and color printer.

loans.name: Janifa

texts.en:
Janifa K. is currently in the business of selling cartons of salt, bags of beans and soda in a shop. She is requesting a loan to stock more crates of soda and bags of beans to sell.

Janifa is 33 years old and is married with a husband who is a business man. She has five children and her children go to school.

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To stock more crates of soda and bags of beans to sell.

loans.name: Chuluuntsetseg

texts.en:
Chuluuntsetseg B. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent. Her daughter, age 7, attends a local elementary school.

She and her husband operate a consumer goods retail business out of two different places in their town. They started their business in 2002 by operating a meat trading business between 2002 and 2003 after moving to their current town. Since 2004 they have been selling a variety of products that have been imported from China.

In the future, Chuluuntsetseg plans to expand her business by opening a branch shop and having their own work place. She is a talkative and open minded woman and says, "My dream is to have my own apartment where my family can live." She is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan in order to increase her working capital for her consumer goods trading business.

loans.use: To buy more consumer goods.

loans.name: Enhee

texts.en:
Enhee C. is 50 years old and lives with her son in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. Her son, age 15, attends a local high school.

Enhee operates a tailoring business out of her home. She has been making a variety of traditional clothes since 1999 and has gained a lot of experience as a seamstress. She usually sells her products to the traditional clothes seller at the local market in the town.

For the future, she hopes to continue running her business as a stable operation. Enhee is a talkative and open minded woman. Her goal is to provide a good education for her son. She is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to increase her working capital for her sewing business.

loans.use: To buy more materials.

loans.name: Maimuma

texts.en:
Maimuma T. is currently in the business of selling onions, beans and simsim (sesame) and is requesting a loan to stock more beans, onions and rice to sell.  Maimuma is 40 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant. She has three children and her children go to school.

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a house.

loans.use: Stock more beans, onions and rice to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Jamila Joldosheva's Group

texts.en: Jamila J. is the leader of this group. She is 44 and married. Together with her husband they bring up two children. Both of them study at school. Since 1989 the family has been running their own business. The source of income lies in the sphere of trading, precisely vegetables selling. Out of their business profits the family was able to afford purchasing a house and car. In order to open a new facility to raise more money and make possible building a new house, Jamila wants to increase the quantity of goods she has to sell. This is the main aim of getting the loan. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Kov

texts.en: Kov T. is a 62-year-old woman and a widow; her husband died of senility a year ago. Kov T. is a local farmer who has been living in Phnom Penh City, and she owns and operates her farm to cultivate rice. She currently lives with her children, as her two children are single and living under her management. Both of her children work at sewing clothes in the garment factory. Kov T.’s children complain that it is hard to travel to work because they don’t have a vehicle. They go to work by taxi or they walk. Kov T. is therefore applying for a loan to purchase a motorcycle for her child to ride to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her child to ride to work.

loans.name: Jumadil

texts.en: Jumadil I. is a 51-year-old farmer, who lives in the north of Kyrgyzstan. He is married and has three children. He was a watchman at the telecommunication plant and his wife worked as a cleaner, but both of them were not well-paid. For this reason, Jumadil decided to engage in cattle breeding with the initial capital of 8,000 Kyrgyz Soms. Owing to his persistent and hardworking personality, Jumadil managed to multiply his investments. With the revenues, he managed to buy a used car and renovate his house. At present, his farm has two milk cows, 10 sheep and 12 goats. Jumadil plans to use this loan of 100,000 Kyrgyz Soms to broaden the number of cattle for fattening and reselling. In future, Jumadil plans to build a barn for the cattle. About Bai-Tushum and Partners Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Erdenetuul

texts.en:
Erdenetuul U. is 32 years old and lives with her husband, three daughters and son in Bayanhongor province in Mongolia. All six members of the family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her older two children both attend a local secondary school.

Erdentuul and her husband work in the family’s traditional shoemaking business out of their home. She began her own business in 1998 after assisting two people to make a variety of traditional boots in 1996. After many years of owning this business, she has gained significant experience as a shoemaker. For the future, she plans to expand her business and have her own work place. She is a hardworking person and is requesting a 120,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more materials to make boots.

loans.use: To purchase more materials.

loans.name: Isan

texts.ru: Назиров Исан проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 55 лет. Женат. Имеет троих детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сын на заработках в России. Сам Исан имеет среднее образование. Более 5 лет занимается торговлей. Арендует помещение, в котором открыл продуктовый магазин. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: Isan N. lives in Shahrituz. He is 55 years old, married, and has three children.  His wife is a housewife. His son works in Russia.  Isan has a secondary education.  He has been working in sales for more than five years. He rents a space in which he has opened a grocery shop. He is taking out a loan to increase sales.

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 28-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and five siblings. He has over seven years of experience working with car rental. He independently owns his own business. His work consists in purchasing used cars and selling them after doing the needed maintenance. With his requested  loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l., he will increase his business capital by performing maintenance needed for his cars including renovating the paint jobs so as to be able to resell them and make a good profit. The income from his business is an important source of income for himself and his family. He is confident that his work will continue to be successful in the coming year.

In the future, he is working to open a bigger store to buy and sell cars and spare parts. He told us that he would like to one day open a commercial center.

loans.use: performing maintenance needed for his cars including renovating the paint jobs to be able to resell them and make a good profit

loans.name: Gerelmaa

texts.en:
Gerelmaa N. is 26 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her daughter, age 6, attends a local elementary school. Her husband is a driver and operates a taxi service which he started in 2005.

Since August 2010, Gerelmaa has been managing a clothing trade business in a rented stall at the local trade center. Before starting her business, she also operated a taxi after purchasing her own car. For the future, Gerelmaa hopes to continue to expand her business and improve her car.

Gerelmaa says, "I hope to one day own my own stall." She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more winter clothes to sell at her stall for the upcoming winter months.

loans.use: To purchase more winter clothes to sell.

loans.name: Sveta's Group

texts.en:
Sveta N. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Tokmok. Sveta by herself has raised two daughters. Both daughters are married and live separately with their families.

Sveta makes money running her own business selling potatoes. Five years ago together with her friends, this businesslike woman decided to increase her welfare, and out of her profits she has managed to obtain an apartment. Further she intends to purchase a container and to make house repairs. In order to maintain and multiply her income, Sveta wants to increase the turnover of her business and for this purpose she hopes to obtain a loan.

Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan.

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase more potatoes for sale.

loans.name: Jamiyansuren

texts.en: Jamiyansuren J. is 26 years old and lives with his wife and infant twin sons in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. They live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His wife is an economist and currently unemployed while taking care of their sons. Jamiyansuren is an engineer and operates a cellphone selling and repair business in his town. He started his cellphone business in 2010 after working in the local television center. He has established himself in the local business community and has a steady operation. He is a very hardworking and open-minded person who hopes expand his business in the future. He hopes to one day have his own electronic appliance trade center in his town. Jamiyansuren is requesting a 900,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase cellphone parts for his business.

loans.use: To purchase cellphone parts

loans.name: Janylbubu's Group

texts.en: Janylbubu is the leader of this group. At 49, she is unfortunately a widow. By herself she takes care of, raises and gives proper upbringing to her two sons, both of whom are university students. In order to support the family financially, Janylbubu earns money by working as an operator in the Tokmok filling station. Besides that, she is engaged in cattle breeding. She is a hardworking woman who wants to improve the well-being of her family and for this reason, she intends to develop her business concerning cattle breeding. She wants to purchase cattle to feed and then resell at a higher price. For this purpose, she hopes to get a loan. In the future, Janylbubu aims to present her son with a musical instrument. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Seraphine

texts.en:
Seraphine is 34, married with five children, aged between 1 and 12 years old. Seraphine’s husband does not work and so she works extra hard to provide all the basic necessities for her family.  Seraphine owns a small business selling various products.  It is known in the area and well organized. She works from  6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day.

Seraphine has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase additional products for her store.  After increasing the range of products in her shop, Seraphine will be able to earn more profit to help provide for her family.

loans.use: Purchasing additional products to sell

loans.name: Lhagvasuren

texts.en: Lhagvasuren M. is 48 years old and lives with his wife and five children in Uvs province, Mongolia. His older three children, ages 19, 21 and 22, all are university students and his younger two children attend a local high school. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Lhagvasuren operates a coal-selling business in his town with the help of his wife. He purchases coal directly from local mines and uses his large Russian truck to transport back to his town. His wife helps him sell the coal to various local businesses and individuals for use in heating. He has operated this business since 1994 and has gained much experience over the years. He has a large customer base with many loyal clients and hopes to purchase a larger truck in the future to keep up with growing demand. He sells five to six trucks of coal and earns around 400,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT). He says, "I work hard to provide a good education for my all children." He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase three trucks of coal and one truck of firewood to sell.

loans.use: To purchase three trucks of coal

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 19-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his family. Despite his young age, he is a proud new business owner; he has worked as a home electrician since 2007. He independently owns his personal business. Due to his newest experience in this field, he takes on small projects in addition of repairing home electricity upon request of the clients. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1100 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional electric tools and a special electric machine for his business.  The income from his business is an important source of income for himself and his family. He is confident that his work will continue to be successful in the coming year. In the future, he is working to take on more and bigger projects to build a good business reputation.

loans.use: to purchase additional electric tools and a special electric machine for his business

loans.name: Opani

texts.en:
Opani R. is currently in the business of selling onions, simsim (sesame) and beans and is requesting a loan to stock more beans and simsim to sell.  Opani is 28 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. She has four children and only one child goes to school.

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: To stock more beans and simsim to sell.

loans.name: Karkay Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Karkay” group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve on their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Marie B.. Marie is age 46. She was born in Magburaka town where she is currently residing together with her husband and four children. Her husband is a businessman and three of her children are attending primary and secondary schools, respectively. For seven years now, Marie has been selling slippers, lace cloths, ready-to-wear-clothes, etc. With this loan, she will buy slippers, lace cloths, ready-to-wear-clothes, at wholesale to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy slippers, lace cloths, ready-to-wear-clothes, at wholesale to add to her business

loans.name: Abizerana Group

texts.fr: Médiatrice N. est commerçante de poules, et elle est un membre du groupe Abizerana, un groupe de femmes entrepreneurs.  Elle à 23 ans, elle est mariée, et elle a 2 enfants entre 1 an et 5 ans.  Elle va utilisée son prêt pour sa commerce de poules.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est de travailler avec le banc pour augmenter son chiffre d’affaire.  Elle voudrait devenir grossiste, et aussi scolariser ses enfants.
texts.en: Médiatrice N. has a business selling chickens. She is a member of the group Abizerana, which is a group of female entrepreneurs. She is 23 years old, married and the mother of two children between the ages of one and five years old. She will use this loan for her chicken business. Her strategy for the growth of her business is to work with the bank in order to increase her profits. She would like to become a wholesaler and also to educate her children.

loans.use: Commerce de poules

loans.name: Badal

texts.ru: Мунаварова Бадал проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 63 года. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее. Уже девять лет как занимается торговлей. Рядом с домом имеет магазин, где продает запасные части велосипеда и стройматериалы. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en: Badal M. lives in Shahrituz. She is 63 years old, married, and has four children. She has a  secondary education. She has been trading for nine years. She has a shop near her house where she sells spare bicycle parts and building materials.  She is taking out a loan to increase the variety of goods she carries.

loans.use: Increase the variety of goods

loans.name: Farizat Mambetova's Group

texts.en: Farizat M. has a traditional Kyrgyz family consisting of five members. Her husband helps to give proper upbringing to their three daughters. The eldest of their daughters is a student, the second one is a schoolgirl, and the youngest goes to kindergarten. The adult family members contribute to their common budget in different ways: the head of the family is an employee of the District Department of Inner Affairs and his salary comes to 15,000 soms per month; Farizat raises money by helping a kindergarten teacher; the eldest daughter helps her parents financially by working as a yard-keeper. At the same time, the family is occupied in cattle breeding. The total earnings from these activities make it possible to purchase the necessary household items. A large family has large requirements. Therefore in order to improve their well-being, Farizat wants to increase the total number of animals they keep. For this aim, she plans to buy two sheep. This is the main purpose for getting this loan. In the future, the family hopes to make their intention to buy a new house come true. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase sheep.

loans.name: Umugisha Group

texts.fr: Philibert U. a un atelier de menuiserie, et il est un membre du groupe Umugisha  sake.  Il a 27 ans, et il est célibataire.  Il va utilise son prêt pour son atelier de menuiserie.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est le service en or, et de fournisse le mobilière de bureau.  Il voudrait avoir beaucoup de machines d’atelier de menuiserie.  Aussi, il voudrait se marier, et construire une maison.
texts.en: Philibert U. has a carpentry workshop and is a member of the group called Umugisha in Sake. He is 27 years old and single. He will use this loan for his carpentry workshop. His strategy for growing his business is excellent service and to build office furniture. He would like to have many woodworking machines in his workshop. Also, he would like to marry and to build a house.

loans.use: Carpentry workshop

loans.name: Amos

texts.en:
Amos is a married man with four children .He lives in a permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda. He dreams of opening up a boutique for brand new clothing and in the process transforming his second-hand clothing boutique which he is operating. He also dreams of educating his children so that they can have a better future. 

Amos wants a loan to purchase second-hand clothes to sell at his shop.

loans.use: Purchasing second-hand clothes to sell at his shop

loans.name: Ta Marr Group

texts.en: Kumba T. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Kumba was born in a place call Bendugu, about 42 years ago. She is married to a policeman and the couple has six children, three of whom are still attending schools. For over eight years now, Kumba has been selling clothes and trousers. With the help of this loan, Kumba and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently, improve their living conditions. Kumba will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to buy clothes and trousers at wholesale to add to her current ones.

loans.use: To buy clothes and trousers at wholesale to add to her current ones

loans.name: Toktobubu Japarova's Group

texts.en: Toktobubu J. is married to a farmer. She is 44 and together with her spouse she gives upbringing to three daughters, all of them schoolgirls. As average villagers, the family makes money by keeping poultry. All the family members are engaged in this business and all of them are interested in increasing the family budget. One of the Tortobubu’s main wishes concerns the improvement of her family's welfare. She hopes to make it come true by developing her business and for this reason she needs to purchase poultry. Therefore she applies to obtain a loan. In the future, she hopes to purchase a washing-machine. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase poultry.

loans.name: Zamu

texts.en:
Zamu T. lives in the Kawempe Mbogo neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has five children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of her old mother. Zamu lives in a home that she owns and she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and paying utility bills.   

Zamu has a business of selling bananas. She has been in this business for seven years, and she works six days out of every week. Zamu sells her products at the market, by means of wholesale/retail.

Zamu has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas.

The main business challenges for Zamu include thieves, the rainy season and transportation.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas.

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward O. M. is 26 years old. For a living, he repairs electronics and sells electronics on a small scale. His business, "M. Electronics", is located in a conducive environment.

Edward is requesting a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy electronics like TVs and DVD players for sale.

Edward is married and is a father to one. He hopes to be a successful businessman owning a chain of electronics sales businesses. He describes himself as hardworking and determined.

loans.use: To buy electronics like TVs and DVD players for sale.

loans.name: Gulzat Kushubakova's Group

texts.en: Gulzat K. is the leader of this group. She is 25 and married. Together with her husband they raise two sons, both of them of preschool age. Generally the family capital is being raised by Gulzat’s husband. In the past four years he has increased his budget by selling cattle. He decided to start running this business after following practical advice. Currently he is operating the business together with his brother in the local cattle market. Out of his profits he has managed to build a house. The family needs are growing as the children are growing. Considering this fact, the head of the family wants to increase profits and for this purpose Gulzat is requesting a loan for the family business. Their future plans include selling an old car in order to obtain a new one. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a twenty-two-year-old married man, with one child. He lives in his semi-permanent house in Kyenjojo, Uganda. Moses is very hardworking; he is charged with the responsibility of looking after his child and wife. His desire is to buy a car. He runs a boutique with an experience of four years in this business which is very feasible. He has been able to reap profits and wants to have a modern boutique in town.

He intends to invest the loan in buying trousers, shirts, dresses, shoes to sell at his shop.

loans.use: Buying trousers, shirts, dresses, and shoes to sell at his shop

loans.name: Aigul Sydykova's Group

texts.en: Aigul S. has an average rural way of life. Her family is rather big including six members. The eldest son is 22 and he is currently in military service as a platoon leader commander position; the second child is a student; another is a schoolboy; the youngest infant – a small daughter who is only three - just begins to learn this world. The whole family lives on profits from cattle breeding and farming. As well, Aigul’s husband, being the head of the family, earns additionally by working as a builder. Their earnings make it possible to give children proper education. Preparing for winter, the family wants to purchase some warm clothes. For this purpose they need extra money, that’s why a loan is hoped to be got. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase winter clothes.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a twenty-six-year-old woman, living in her family's permanent house in Kyenjojo, Uganda. Her desire is to have a big family business. She has a retail shop which is very feasible although with a challenge of limited capital due to the ever increasing demand. Nevertheless, Sarah has been able to reap profits and wants to be a wholesale trader.

She intends to invest the loan in purchasing sugar, soap, salt, and cooking oil to sell at her shop.

loans.use: Purchasing sugar, soap, salt, and cooking oil to sell at her shop

loans.name: Tatay Sumpa Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of the “Tatay Sumpa” group from Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Hawa T. is the leader of this group. The 50-year-old is married to a businessman and they have five children. Hawa sells cooked rice, cooked foofoo (food made out of cassava roots), and fried cakes. She has been a businesswoman for 10 years now.  With her share of this loan, she will buy cooking ingredients: palm oil, rice, onions, etc. at wholesale.

loans.use: To buy cooking ingredients – palm oil, rice, onions, etc. at wholesale

loans.name: Farida

texts.ru: Ниёзматова Фарида проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 31 год. Замужем, имеет двоих детей. Муж, работает таксистом. Сама Фарида имеет среднее образование. Работает на рынке района. Она имеет торговую точку, где продает запасные части велосипеда. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже восемь лет. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en: Farida N. lives in Shahrituz.  She is 31 years old, married, and has two children. Her husband works as a taxi driver.  Farida has a secondary education. She works in the local market.  She has a shop where she sells bicycle spare parts. She has been doing this work for eight years. She is taking out a loan to increase the variety of goods she carries.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas E. O. O. is a forty-year-old businessman who runs Joyland Community School in Nairobi. He is married and a father to three. To earn more income, he owns a barber shop and a salon that his wife runs.

Nicholas is requesting a loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase school desks and text books. He describes himself as visionary, ambitious and focused. He plans to build his school into a successful primary school with better results in five years.

loans.use: To purchase school desks and text books.

loans.name: Mirismayil

texts.en: Mirismayil M. is a 27 years old trader who runs his own business in the Agsu city of Azerbaijan. He has two years of experience selling phone accessories.  With the first loan from Kiva and AqroInvest he started a business selling men's clothes and now he has two shops. He decided to open a new shop but in a different area and discovered that the phone accessories business is more profitable and can generate constant income. Now this business brings him enough profit to cover the needs of his wife and two children.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise to increase profit.

loans.name: Inkundamahoro Group

texts.fr: Deo Mussa N. est commerçant, et il est un membre du groupe Inkunsamahoro.  Il est marié, et il n’a pas d’enfants.  Avec son prêt, il veut acheter les sorghos et haricots pour les détailler en sa boutique.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’épargne sur le compte dans deux semaines.  Il voudrait avoir la capacité d’autofinancement.  Pour sa famille, il voudrait satisfaire leur besoins.
texts.en: Deo Mussa N. is a merchant. He is a member of Inkundamahoro Group. He is married without children. He wants to use his loan to buy sorghum and beans and retail them in his store. The growth strategy of his business is to save money in his account within two weeks. He would like his business to become self-financing. He wants to provide for the needs of his family.

loans.use: To buy sorghum and beans

loans.name: Bolotbek

texts.en: Bolotbek M. is 39, married and has three children of school age. He lives in Dobolu village and engages in cattle breeding. He started this business in 1990 in order to earn a living and support his family. With initial capital of only 1,200 Kyrgyz Soms, Bolotbek worked hard to make his business successful. In 2009, he applied for his first loan for purchasing cattle, which he used as intended and repaid without any delays. Using the revenues from selling fattened cattle, he was able to buy a used car for his family. Today Bolotbek’s farm accounts for three milk cows, five goats, four sheep and one horse. Bolotbek plans to use this loan of 60,000 Kyrgyz Soms to broaden his business by purchasing bull calves. With the revenues from this investment, Bolotbek plans to reconstruct his barn. Bai-Tushum and Partners Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Roben

texts.en:
Roben is a thirty-five year old married man with six children. He lives in a semi-permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda.  He dreams of building rentals to increase avenues of income for his family, buying a car, and opening up a store in Kampala.

He wants a loan to buy maize and beans for resale.

loans.use: Buying maize and beans to resell at a profit

loans.name: Yolamu

texts.en:
Yolamu, aged 38, is a married man with seven children. He lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He has operated a retail shop for the last seven years. He started with capital worth one hundred thousand which he had saved up from farming. He deals in buying and selling general domestic merchandise like sugar, toothpaste, soap, and cooking oil. He intends to start up a wholesale shop from his business proceeds in the near future. 

Yolamu wants the loan to purchase sugar, salt, cooking oil, and soap to sell at his shop.

loans.use: Purchasing sugar, salt, cooking oil, and soap to sell at his shop

loans.name: Topista

texts.en: Topista is thirty-four years old and a single mother with four children. She runs a bar in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda. She dreams of expanding her business, buying land, and constructing a residential house. She wants a loan to buy beer, soda and wine for resale.

loans.use: Buying beer, soda and wine to resell

loans.name: Shafiga

texts.en:
Shafiga M. is a married woman with four children. She has a very hard life caring for such a big family. She started a business in 2003 and since that time she has become very successful and was able to open a men's clothes shop.  Now she is doing great and her husband helps her in this business.

Shafiga has applied for 1000 AZN loan to increase her income by buying more clothes to sell. Shafiga recently finished her loan from Kiva and promises to repay on time as she did with her first loan.

loans.use: To purchase more seasonal clothes.

loans.name: David

texts.en: David K. G. is 54 years old and he has been selling sugarcane for three years in a busy environment. He is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to increase his stock of sugarcane. David also sells water and owns rental houses. He is a married father of seven and he hopes to buy a pick-up truck for transporting sugarcane for sale in wholesale markets.

loans.use: To increase his stock of sugarcane.

loans.name: Samir

texts.en:
Samir A. is a 30 years old entrepreneur who sells different kinds of food in Agsu city. He is married and has three children. He started his business in 2005 and since that time he is doing well. His primary clients are people living near his shop. He has about 200 AZN monthly income.

Now Samir has applied for a 1000 AZN loan to increase his income and provide better life conditions for his family. He already finished his first loan from AqroInvest successfully and now promises to pay back accurately once more.

loans.use: To purchase more food to increase income.

loans.name: Kishegyere Kwetungura Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
M. Francis is the leader of Kishegyere Kwetungura group in Kihihi. He is 36 years old and married with five children, four of whom are in school.
Francis is involved in growing tea and selling tea leaves to Kayonza tea factory in Kihihi. He says that out of his sales plus the sale of coffee, he is able to make 240,000 UGX as monthly profits. At times when his output is small, he buys tea leaves from other farmers and supplies them to the factory. This is why he now needs a loan to buy more tea leaves and also expand his tea farm. Francis has been in this business for ten years and having a ready market has benefited him a lot.

loans.use: To buy more tea leaves and expand his tea farm

loans.name: Priscah

texts.en: Priscah is 26 years old. She sells fish in one of the largest markets in Nairobi. She employs two people and her customers are reliable and loyal. She has been in this business for seven years and hopes to diversify into selling kerosene in the future. She describes herself as hardworking and determined to succeed. Priscah is married and a mother of five. She plans to be selling fish wholesale in five years time. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to add stocks of omena (baby fish) and tilapia to her business.

loans.use: To add stock of omena (baby fish) and tilapia

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Kelly

texts.en: Kelly sells bedsheets for a living and is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase bedsheets to sell. She is 42 years old and married with three children. She hopes to be financially independent in the future with a big business. This is her first loan and it is guaranteed by Nairobi Hair Beauty Forum SHG. She describes herself as honest and hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase bedsheets to sell

loans.name: Hands Together Ii Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Hands Together II” group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Waterloo, a small-town in western Sierra Leone where “Shine on Sierra Leone” partnered with SMT to start a branch. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and, consequently, improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Hawa K.. Hawa is 27. She was born in Yeleh village but she is currently residing in Waterloo together with her husband and three children. Her husband is a driver and her children are attending both primary and secondary schools, respectively. For five years now, Hawa has been selling slippers, toothpaste, toothbrushes, body lotions, etc. With this loan, will buy the above-mentioned items at wholesale to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy slippers, toothpaste, toothbrushes, body lotions, etc. at wholesale to add to her business

loans.name: Hyginus

texts.en:
N. Hyginus is an individual client from Ibanda. He is 41 years old and married with four children, three of whom are in school.
Hyginus is a businessman who buys and sells cattle from Mahega. He is helped by casual laborers in order to manage his business. His customers are mostly people in his locality. From his sales, he is able to make 220,000 UGX as monthly profits. Before the cattle sales business, Hyginus used to sell bananas, and it is savings from his salary and business that he moved to his current business ten years ago. He is requesting a loan to purchase two cows and a plot of land. Hyginus is a hardworking man with the aim of growing his business further.

loans.use: To purchase two cows and a plot of land

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard C. is 41 years old and lives in the town of Litein in western Kenya. He is married with 10 children, between the ages of 1 and 22. Seven of the 10 are currently attending school. He has been in the business of farming for 10 years. In addition to running the farm, he also earns income working as a carpenter.

Richard is requesting a loan of 25,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. Doing so will improve his farm's milk production. With the expected increase in income from the loan, Richard hopes to improve his business by purchasing at least two more dairy cows.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Azad

texts.en:
Azad A. is a 50-year-old man who has raised cattle for the last three years. He is married and has four children. He buys cattle for a profitable price, fattens them and sells to the local butchers or takes them once a week to the livestock bazaar. His monthly income is about 300-400 AZN and he is on the way to increase it to 500 AZN.

As soon as he successfully finished his first loan from Kiva he applied for a new one. He promises to pay it back as well as he did the first one.

loans.use: To purchase two cattle and fodder.

loans.name: Amigas Unidas Group

texts.es:
Para la formación del presente comité inició la señora Elvira, de Yguazú. Ella contactó con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en la zona. El comité se denomina Amigas Unidas, están en el Sexto Ciclo con 13  integrantes. Es un grupo muy unido, solidario y responsable, las integrantes poseen un gran espíritu emprendedor, ya que están al día con las cuotas, realizan actividades de recaudación de fondos, como también de motivación, y pretenden terminar esta etapa con muy buen cumplimiento de responsabilidad con la institución. 

Una de las integrantes es la señora Elva quien se dedica a la venta de ropas y remedios yuyos. Lo realiza en un salón de su casa y también ofrece sus productos de manera ambulante, recorriendo los negocios de sus clientes.
De esta forma, ella vende sus productos y así obtiene los ingresos para sus familias y de esta forma cubre algunos gastos que necesariamente se realiza todos los días en la familia, como sin la alimentación. 
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de ropas y remedios yuyos.
texts.en:
The formation of the present committee was started by Mrs. Elvira, of Yguazú. She contacted her neighbors and friends to form the committee in her area. The committee is called Amigas Unidas [United Friends] and they are in their sixth cycle with 13 members. It is a very united, supportive and responsible group. The members possess a very motivational and enterprising spirit. They are on target for meeting the quotas for their businesses and the collection of funds. They expect to finish this stage with very good performance in meeting their obligations with the institution. 

One of the members is Mrs. Elva, who sells clothes and herbal medicines out of a room in her home. She also offers her services by visiting her customers' businesses. In this manner, she is able to sell her products and earn an income for her family to cover some expenses that are necessary in the daily life of the family, such as basic nutrition. She is requesting the loan to purchase clothing and herbal medicines.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing and herbal medicines.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy.

loans.name: Mazakhir

texts.en:
Mazakhir K. is 51 years old man who is an independent businessman who is engaged in various activities.  In 2004 he started a small retail business along with construction materials sales and now he has his own shop where he sells electronic goods.  

He is married and has two sons who actively help him in his business.  From the first loan he was able to generate enough income to open his own shop. Now he has two businesses:  construction materials sales and electrical goods sale. The shops brings him stable income and he is going to enlarge it. Now Mazakhir has applied for 1,000 AZN to increase the inventory.

loans.use: To increase the amount of merchandise to increase profit.

loans.name: Abibatu

texts.en:
This is 35 year-old Abibatu F.. She is married, and has two children aged two and four years. In 1990, Abibatu established her ladies' slippers and sandals business. She began her business because she believed the business could be a means of generating income to sustain her family. Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about 2,350,000 SLL every month from this business.

Abibatu requires a loan of 4,500,000 SLL in order to expand her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 400,000 SLL.

In the future, Abibatu plans to open a bigger shop and support her children to university level. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more ladies slippers and sandals.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Sahr Brima

texts.en:
This is 35 year-old Sahr Brima B.. He is single, and has one child aged two years. In 2006, Sahr established a plastic utensils business. He began his business because he believed it can make him self-reliant. Working seven days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about 2,418,000 SLL every month from this business. He needs a loan in the amount of 4,500,000 SLL.

Sahr has a very good loan repayment history. He requires a new loan in order to buy more stock. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 500,000 SLL. He is a serious and determined business man and he thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more plastic utensils.

loans.name: Mgombolwa Group

texts.en:
Grace M. is in her late thirties and is married with four children. Grace has been running her own fruit and vegetable stall since 2005. Grace starts working at 4:00 am when she goes down to the market to buy her goods, she then sells them until 7:00 pm in the afternoon. The business earns Grace a low monthly profit.

This will be Grace's fourth loan with Tujijenge Tanzania. Grace used her previous loans to improve her stall and increase her business. She also used parts of the loans to buy bricks to construct a new house. These loans were all successfully repaid. With this loan, Grace aims to increase her business as well buy more bricks for the construction of her new house. Grace's dream is to finish her house and keep improving her business.

Grace will share this loan with her loan group Mgombolwa, which has 16 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the picture, Grace can be seen in front row, first on the left and wearing pink.

loans.use: Increase business and to buy more bricks to construct a home.

loans.name: Elephant Group

texts.en:
Said C. is in his mid-thirties and is married with one daughter. Said has been running his tailoring business since 1998. The store is open between 8:00 am and 5:30 pm and earns Said a low monthly profit. 

This will be Said's fourth loan with Tujijenge Tanzania. Said used his previous loans to buy a new sewing machine and cloth for his business. These loans have now been successfully repaid. Business has since been going well and with his fourth loan Said aims to buy another sewing machine as he has recently been able to hire more help for the business. 

Said will share this loan with his loan group Elephant, which totals 20 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the picture, Said can be seen as the first on the right wearing a blue shirt.

loans.use: To buy another sewing machine

loans.name: Unity Group

texts.en:
Asia Abdalah is in her late twenties and is married with two children. Asia runs a food stall which she has been operating since 2004. Asia sells different types of bananas, mainly those used for cooking. The stall is open daily between 7:00 am and 3:00 pm and earns Asia a low monthly profit. 

This will be Asia's fourth loan with Tujijenge Tanzania. Asia's previous loans were used to increase her business, and  to provide her with extra capital to quickly restock when running out of goods. These loans were all successfully repaid. With her fourth loan, Asia aims to increase her business and again provide liquidity so that she can stock up quickly when needed. 

Asia will share this loan with her loan group, Unity, which totals 18 members. the members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the picture, Asia can be seen in the front row, first on the right and holding a baby.

loans.use: To increase her business

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 32 years old. He is married with three children who all attend school. He is a farmer from Nyamira Town in Western Kenya. He has been farming  for ten years and employs six farmhands. His products are tea, milk, maize and beans which he sells locally.

He also earns money from his chemist business which he operates in the same region. 

He has requested this loan of KES 45,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to acquire a quality dairy cow that will increase his milk production. The extra income from the sale of milk will enable him to pay school fees for his children. 

His main challenges have been unreliable workers and poor weather conditions, especially hailstorms which destroy his crops.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Bwashwa Tukore Group A, Kihihi

texts.en: M. Amos is the leader of his lending group, Bwashwa Tukore A. He is 41 years old and married with eight children. He has a tea growing and selling business, from which he is able to make 150,000 shillings as monthly profits. M. also owns banana and coffee plantations, which continue to give him an income after sales. Just like many farmers, Amos has been selling his tea leaves to the factory in the area for over 10 years. He is a determined and focused man with a dream to expand his business further.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and manure

loans.name: Lokumu Plus Group

texts.en:
Jeanine M. is the manager of the group “Lokumu Plus,” made up of ten members. They are firmly united to receive loans from the MFI (micro-finance institution) HOPE RDC in order to develop their businesses.

Jeanine runs a general store and sells second-hand clothing in her area. She has been a micro entrepreneur for years. She has good relationships with her customers. She likes her business and is working hard to achieve her goal of ordering bundles of second-hand clothing from abroad. She is a loyal client of the MFI HOPE RDC, who has already received five different loans and has repaid them properly. 

She intends to use the next loan to buy two bundles of used clothing to resell to increase her profits. Each week, her business brings in a profit of $50. Jeanine is 40 years old, married and the mother of two children who are 23 and 24 years old. Both are students.

loans.use: To purchase two bundles of used clothing and resell them at a profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Bokoli Plus Group

texts.en:
Mado T., is the President of the Community Bank named “Bokoli Plus” which is composed of 17 micro-entrepreneurs. These members are united for the same goal: to grow their businesses with loans received from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC. 

Mado is 43 years old; her activity is to sell soft drinks. She buys crates of soft drinks and resells them by the piece at a profit. She sells her products daily in her area.

Mado started her business in 2000. She is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having ten times obtained and correctly repaid loans. Her next loan will allow her to buy crates of soft drinks and women’s clothing in larger quantities to increase her sales in order to make a better profit. 

Mado makes a profit of about US$13 per day. The aims of this loan are mainly to generate income for food and school fees for her children. She is married and the mother of four children. She also is responsible for nine others (children and grandchildren).

loans.use: buying crates of soft drinks and women’s clothing in large quantities

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
This is 28-year-old Fatmata.  She is married and has 2 children aged 5 and 14. She has two additional dependents, who live with her because they are her husband’s relatives. In the year 2000, Fatmata established her men’s shoes and ladies' slippers business. Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about 2,771,000 SLL every month from this business. She needs a loan of 4,500,000 SLL.

Fatmata has a very good loan repayment history. She now requires a new loan to help her buy more business stock. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 800,000 SLL. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more shoes and  slippers

loans.name: Bwashwa Tukore Group B, Kihihi

texts.en:
Peace Kaconco has a retail shop in the Bwashwa trading center where she sells salt, sugar and soft drinks to the local people. She has been in business for five years and makes 60,000 UGX in monthly profits. She also grows food to sell.

Peace is a new Pearl Microfinance client and belongs to Bwashwa Tukore Group B. She needs a loan to buy more stock for resale. Being a hard worker has enabled her to grow, as well as allowed her children to study. She hopes for the best.

loans.use: To restock her shop with more merchandise

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam N. lives in the  Ndeeba neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.She is married and has 4 children, all of whom are in school. Mariam has a business selling charcoal .She has been in this business for 7 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Mariam sells her products at the market, wholesale.  

Mariam has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal . The main business challenges for Mariam include thieves and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are owning a delivery van. Mariam lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and paying rent .

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Amid

texts.en:
Amid H. is a 31-year-old butcher who sells meat in Sabirabad city. He is married and has one son. He is not alone in his business as his brother helps him. Once a week he and his brother go to the livestock market to buy cattle at a profitable price.  

Amid also purchases cattle from local farmers sometimes, but would like to have his own livestock to be able to cover client demand.  His butcher shop is located in Sabirabad central bazaar which makes his business successful. He applied for a 1000 AZN loan to purchase cattle, raise them, and be able to sell them for meat  as needed.

loans.use: purchase two cows to raise for meat

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is a forty-nine-year-old married and enterprising man living in his own house with five children in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is charged with the responsibility of providing the basics to the family all alone. He envisions having an educated family with a blissful family business. 

For five years he has been working with a water company and this has enabled him to pay school fees and complete his house. Vincent needs the loan to pay school fees for his children

loans.use: Paying school fees for his children

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul S. is 41 years old and married with three children who are all in school. He lives in Ibanda and is involved in the sale of bananas from Akebumba village. Paul also has a produce store in the same area from which he sells such products as sugar cane, tomatoes and coffee. He is able to make 360,000 UGX from his monthly sales.

Paul is requesting a loan so he can expand his produce business. He first grew tomatoes, then started selling bananas as well. Paul is a hardworking and cooperative man. His dream is to expand his business further as well as educating his children.

loans.use: To expand his business by growing more tomatoes and buying more bananas for resale

loans.name: Compressor Group

texts.en:
Goodliva B. is in her mid-thirties and is married with three children.  Goodliva has been running a table top fish selling business for one and a half years.  The shop is open between 7:30 am and 9:00 pm and earns Goodliva a low monthly profit.

This will be Goodliva's third loan with Tujijenge Tanzania.  Goodliva used her previous loans to increase her business and to make sure that she always has enough liquidity to restock if she needed to.  These loans were all successfully repaid.
